insights_for_incidences: Beneficios entity shows an unusual Friday spike pattern (14.60 files vs. typical 1-2 files).
Files appearing on Sunday would be anomalous (consistently zero in historical data).
Files with formats other than CSV would be anomalous (100% CSV historically).
Monday shows minimal activity (mean 1 file overall) with a wider time window (08:06-17:21 UTC).
Most uploads are expected Tuesday-Saturday within 08:00-08:13 UTC.
Saipos entity shows Monday activity (5.50 files) which differs from most entities.
Significant deviations from entity-specific volume patterns would be anomalous.
Wednesday consistently shows the highest volume.
Absence of daily uploads with 7-day coverage would be anomalous.
Absence of weekend processing would be anomalous.
Uploads outside the 07:30-15:30 UTC window across any day would be anomalous.
Lag (filename date → upload timestamp) outside +1 to +3 days would be anomalous.
Non-empty files not consistently showing a maximum of 150,000 rows would be anomalous.
Deviation from Wednesday's peak volume (38.4M rows) or largest file sets would be anomalous.
Monday/Tuesday not having a high empty file rate (>80%) or significantly lower volume than other days would be anomalous.
Deviation from one file per day pattern (mode=1 across all days, with an occasional outlier on Wednesday).
Deviation from consistent 3-day lag between filename date and upload date.
Presence of empty files or files with less than 517 rows.
Gaps of more than one day in daily uploads.
Significant change in file row count compared to historical averages for the relevant period (before/after 2025-05-29).
Absence of active and substantial weekend processing.
File count consistency: Tuesday-Saturday show remarkably consistent file counts (mean 43.15 files/day).
Upload timing: Extremely tight upload window (08:04-08:12 UTC) across all active days.
Empty files: 12 files (1.2% of total), primarily on Monday/Sunday.
Failure files: 10 files (1.0%), all associated with "Saipos" entity.
Multi-part structure: 72% of files follow batch numbering pattern; remainder use date-range format.
Low-volume days: Monday and Sunday consistently show minimal activity (exactly 6 files each).
File size distribution: 21.7% of files contain <100 rows; median 3,868.5 rows across all files.
Coverage: 2025-07-31 to 2025-08-30, 1,000 files with 97.8% successful processing rate.
Timing precision: Remarkable upload time consistency (08:04-08:12 UTC) with extremely low standard deviation.
Day pattern: Clear Tuesday-Saturday active cycle; Monday/Sunday show minimal activity (exactly 6 files each).
Volume distribution: Tuesday shows exceptional peak volume (20.0M rows); Saturday second highest (7.1M rows).
File size characteristics: Highly skewed distribution (mean: 40,694 vs median: 3,868 rows).
Processing reliability: Low failure rate (1.0%) exclusively associated with "Saipos" entity.
Entity distribution: BR appears in 100% of files; sub-entities follow consistent patterns (Settlement 27%, PwGoogle 14%, ApplePay 13%).
Extreme outliers: Max file size (2.57M rows) observed on Tuesday; 95% of files contain <310k rows.
A significant deviation from 5.4% empty files could be anomalous.
Deviations from 2-3 parts or >500k rows for multi-part files could be anomalous.
A lag between filename date and upload date other than 1-2 days (median=1 day) is anomalous.
Uploads occurring outside the 11:01-11:33 UTC window would be anomalous.
Significant change in PIX (~77%) and BANKING (~23%) channel distribution is anomalous.
An increase in processing issues (currently 0.6% stopped, 0.2% deleted) or concentration on specific days might be anomalous.
Absence of consistent daily uploads or deviation from 2 files per day is anomalous.
Significantly lower volume on Wednesday (17.3M rows) and Friday (17.2M rows) might be anomalous.
Files outside the normal range of 0-506,743 rows (95% interval) or significant deviation from the median 83,190 rows per file could be anomalous.
Similar patterns to the Jan-Mar 2025 data-gap period with empty/near-empty files in other periods would be anomalous.
Absence of strong weekend processing (Sat: 12.1M rows, Sun: 9.5M rows) would be anomalous.
Empty files: 319 files (31.9% of total); predominantly associated with __POS channel.
Upload timing: Extremely consistent 11:01-11:44 UTC window (median 11:06 UTC) across all days.
Weekends always have SHOP & PAGO small files; POS files are structurally empty (rows = 0).
No uploads outside schedule window except rare backfills.
Absence of weekday uploads would be anomalous.
Empty file pattern: 31.9% of files contain 0 rows; predominantly __POS channel files.
Day-of-week pattern: Friday shows exceptional peak volume (2.5M rows); Tuesday second highest (520K rows).
Empty files typically constitute 31.9% of total files and are mainly associated with the POS_MARKETPLACE channel (98%).
Empty file distribution varies by day of the week (Mon: 18%, Tue: 15%, Wed: 8%, Thu: 21%, Fri: 9%, Sat: 31%).
Multi-part uploads usually have 3 parts (0000-0002).
Standard upload window is 10:45-12:30 UTC; evening uploads (20:50-21:40 UTC) are rare (<1% of files).
Normal lag between filename date and upload date is 1-2 days; extended lags up to 95 days occur for historical data.
Unexpected bulk upload events might indicate an anomaly.
A consistent pattern of 3 files per day is expected, with no activity on Sundays.
Thursday typically shows peak volume, with Monday being the second highest.
POS files exhibit a binary pattern: either empty or very large.
Gaps in uploads exceeding 24 hours are rare and usually occur during holidays.
Empty files: 8 files (2.39% of total); concentrated in two periods (2025-05-24/25 and 2025-07-21 to 07-31).
Empty file distribution: Slightly higher concentration on weekends (54%) compared to weekdays (46%).
Multi-part uploads: None observed; each statement date corresponds to exactly one file.
Upload timing consistency: Standard pattern: 15:10-15:25 UTC window (mean 15:17 UTC, standard deviation ±5 minutes).
Lag pattern (statement-date → upload-date): Normal flow: 1 day (median, mean = 1.1 days, standard deviation 0.3 days).
File size anomalies: Cluster of micro-files (≤300 rows) between 2025-07-15 and 2025-07-31 (14 files total).
Bulk upload events: One major episode on 2024-12-19 (32 files, historical load of Oct/Nov data).
File pattern: One CSV per calendar date (mode=1 across all days); filename always matches statement date.
Upload timing: Remarkably consistent 15:10-15:25 UTC window (mean 15:17 UTC, standard deviation ±5 minutes).
Volume distribution: Thursday shows highest total (10.8M rows), followed by Monday (10.1M rows).
File size characteristics: Normal range 26,350-261,195 rows (95% interval); median 146,080 rows.
Day-of-week consistency: All days show active processing; weekend volumes comparable to weekdays.
Data volume fluctuations: Short-lived high-volume period in March 2025 and low-volume period in mid-July 2025.
Processing anomalies: Two distinct patterns observed (empty files 2.39%; micro-files ≤300 rows in July 2025).
Uploads outside 14:00-18:00 UTC would be unusual.
Absence of daily uploads would be anomalous.
Appearance of small "micro" files (<=100 rows) in short bursts.
Clear downward trend in file sizes after March 2025 (median ~8k → ~4.5k rows).
Highly regular daily file count pattern (16-19 files per day).
29 recurring entities with consistent presence and predictable file counts.
Expected empty files (24.8% of total) are concentrated in specific entities (Innovation, POC, safemode: 100% empty; Beneficios: ~50% empty; WhiteLabel: ~25% empty).
Upload timing is extremely consistent (08:08-08:18 UTC).
Consistent T+1 lag between filename date and upload date (median 1 day).
All days show active processing with comparable file counts and empty file rates.
Any new entity, date lag >2 days, upload time outside 08:08-08:18 UTC, or multi-part files would be anomalous.
Absence of files on any day would be anomalous.
Upload pattern of two files per day (Debito & MVP) should be consistent; deviation would be anomalous.
Uploads should occur within the established time windows (14:04-14:13 UTC for older data, 08:02-08:11 UTC for newer data).
Filename date to upload date lag should consistently be 1 day (around 24 hours).
A significant increase in 'filtered' zero-row uploads beyond regular occurrence (~4 per month) would be anomalous.
Empty files are expected to be around 3.7% of total and associated with 'filtered' jobs.
Exactly one file per day is expected. Deviation from this is anomalous.
Any processing failure, empty files, or duplicates would be anomalous.
Absence of daily uploads (beyond three allowed gap-days) would be anomalous.
Absence of uploads on any calendar day (including weekends) would be unusual.
Upload times outside the 14:08-18:11 UTC (Feb-May) or 08:03-08:19 UTC (May-Sep) windows are anomalous.
File sizes outside the normal range (45,470-1,884,789 rows) would be anomalous.
Files without the '_BR_3DS' entity after 2025-03-02 are anomalous, as are files with other entities.
A lag pattern (filename date -> upload date) significantly deviating from median 2 days (mean 2.0 days, stdev ±0.2 days) is anomalous.
Empty files are confined to initial backfill period (Feb 20-21); their occurrence afterwards would be anomalous.
More than one file processed per day (or zero files when expected) would be anomalous given the predominant single-file-per-day pattern.
Lag between filename-date and upload-date significantly deviating from 1.1 ± 0.3 days would be anomalous.
Uploads outside the typical window of 14:30-16:30 UTC (with minor daily variations) would be anomalous.
Absence of processing on any day, or lower than expected volumes on weekends (which typically show higher volumes), would be anomalous.
Deleted files not followed by re-upload within 1-3 days would be anomalous.
Frequent or prolonged upload gaps (exceeding approximately 2.5% of days without uploads) would be anomalous.
Deviation from daily upload cadence, especially on weekends, or significantly fewer than 97.5% of days with uploads, would be anomalous.
Weekend uploads outside the typical 14:30-16:30 UTC window would be anomalous.
Significant deviation from expected daily volume distribution, particularly lower volumes on Sunday (highest per-file median) or Monday (highest total), would be anomalous.
File sizes outside the normal range (104,642-739,491 rows) or significantly deviating from the median (473,194.5 rows) would be anomalous.
Weekend volumes lower than weekdays would be anomalous.
Median file size reverting to below 500k rows after March 2025, or a significant, sustained deviation from values >500k rows, would be anomalous.
Predominantly one file per day; more than one file could be anomalous.
Empty files are confined to early January 2025; recurrence would be atypical (<1% since Feb).
Upload timing shows two distinct regimes: Feb-Jun (15:10 UTC ± 20 min) and Jul-Aug (12:15 UTC ± 15 min); uploads outside these windows could be anomalous.
All days (including weekends) show active processing with comparable volumes (10k-30k rows); deviation from this range would be anomalous.
Absence of business day uploads (Mon-Fri) would be anomalous.
Uploads outside the 20:10-20:25 UTC window are anomalous.
Significant deviation from the mean 9.21 files on Thursday could be anomalous.
Consistent high volume activity on Saturday is normal when present, but absence or very low volume should be monitored.
Upload timing outside of the 20:05-20:30 UTC window, or a significant deviation from 20:17 UTC with ±8 minutes standard deviation, would be anomalous.
Significantly lower volume on Thursday (expected 41.4M rows) or Monday (expected 13.5M rows) could indicate an issue.
Deviation from expected volume for '_' merchant (285k-300k rows) is anomalous.
Empty files not associated with 'anota-ai' merchant or a significantly higher percentage of empty files are anomalous.
A higher percentage than 7.5% of files with stopped/failure/deleted status combined is anomalous.
Uploads are expected within a tight window (20:05-20:35 UTC). Any uploads outside this window would be anomalous.
File processing primarily occurs on business days; absence of business day uploads would be anomalous.
Any upload activity on Sunday would be anomalous, as no processing activity is expected.
Thursday typically shows the highest file count (mean 8.5 files); significant deviation could indicate an anomaly.
Thursday shows exceptional peak volume (35.3M rows) and Monday is second highest (9.6M rows); significant deviation from these expected volumes could be anomalous.
Empty files (around 19.1% of total) and large files (up to 1.4M rows) are present in the historical record and should not automatically trigger alerts.
Absence of weekday uploads would be anomalous.
Uploads outside 20:12-20:23 UTC window (excluding bulk backfills at 18:38 UTC) are anomalous.
Merchant '_' files typically have 11k-35k rows; deviations may be anomalous.
Merchant 'anota-ai' files are predominantly small (<50 rows) or empty; larger files may be anomalous.
Monday consolidated files are expected to be between 40k and 55k rows.
Absence of uploads on Wednesday and Thursday could indicate an anomaly, as these days show the highest total volumes.
Significant deviation from the normal file size range (0-36,874 rows) could be anomalous.
High percentage of empty files (9.9%) are associated with stopped status files.
21.7% of files have stopped status, concentrated Tuesday-Thursday.
Merchant 'anota-ai' has a higher failure rate with predominantly small files (0-30 rows), unlike merchant '_' with consistent 11k-20k row files and high success.
Deviation from a median lag of 2.0 days (end-date in filename to upload date) could be anomalous.
Uploads should consistently occur within 20:05-20:23 UTC for most days; Wednesday may have an earlier start (18:41 UTC).
Absence of business day uploads or unexpected weekend activity (especially Sundays) would be anomalous.
Wednesday typically has the highest file count and total volume.
A significant deviation from the observed ~25% decline in typical row counts since June 2025.
Appearance of large files (>50k rows) outside of 1-2 times per month, or not on Mondays/month-opening dates, could be anomalous.
